title: All About the Panda

slides.title: Introduction to the Panda
slides.content: The giant panda (Ailuropoda melanoleuca) is a bear species native to south-central China. Easily recognized by its distinctive black-and-white coloring, the giant panda is beloved worldwide as a symbol of conservation and has been China's national animal since the 1960s.

slides.title: Physical Characteristics
content: Adult giant pandas typically weigh between 200-300 pounds and measure 4-6 feet in length.
Their distinctive black-and-white coloration serves as camouflage in their snowy and rocky mountain habitats.

slides.title: Diet and Feeding Habits
content: Despite being classified as carnivores, 99% of a panda's diet consists of bamboo, consuming 26-84 pounds daily.
Pandas have evolved a specialized wrist bone that functions like a thumb to help them grip bamboo stalks while eating.

slides.title: Behavior and Lifestyle
content: Giant pandas are generally solitary animals, with males and females only coming together during the breeding season.
They spend most of their time eating and resting, with adults sleeping up to 14 hours per day between feeding sessions.

slides.title: Conservation Status
content: Giant pandas were upgraded from 'endangered' to 'vulnerable' in 2016, representing significant conservation success.
Habitat loss and fragmentation remain the biggest threats, though captive breeding and habitat protection programs have helped populations recover.
